title: Thursday, 21st September, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Morning

PM11:01am

So, in the aftermath of Yellen most things pretty much perfectly priced

PM11:01am

Sure, the dollar had to be repriced slightly

11:01 am
PM11:02am

But currencies generally pretty calm

PM11:02am

And as for stocks..

PM11:02am

Well, we're up 6 points

11:02 am
PM11:02am

But that doesn't tell the whole story -- does it Bryce??

PM11:02am

Oh no

PM11:03am

Cos we're straight back talking about market structure - or about the lack of it

11:02 am
PM11:03am

Capita

PM11:03am

There's no support, whatsoever.

PM11:03am

Surely this thing has been crawled over and crawled over

11:03 am
PM11:03am

As has the whole sector

PM11:04am

And yet it can come out with a set of interims where management do their damn best to paper over the cracks

PM11:04am

And the result...

11:04 am
Capita PLC (CPI:LSE): Last: 580.44, down 63.56 (-9.87%), High: 630.00, Low: 551.50, Volume: 3.67m
PM11:04am

Is this warranted? 10% smack?!?

PM11:05am

Figs here https://www.invest...170921070000P4B84/

11:05 am
BE11:05am

Okay, so I remain agnostic to this overarching theory about market inefficiency, and I'm going to argue further that Capita is a tricky example.

PM11:05am

Fair on this being a tricky example

BE11:05am

Because the results in that link up there are just a bloody mess.

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Omg smile

BE11:06am

I mean, the consensus was pretty much bang on.

BE11:06am

The headline numbers are in line. What's out of line is everything else.

11:06 am
PM11:06am

hehehe

BE11:07am

And that's mostly a reflection of Capita having been a slowly smouldering dumpster fire for as long as anyone can remember.

BE11:07am

Let's start with the headlines.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Sure -- in line! -- but only because of a £16m payback from a reshaping of its Defence Infrastructure Organisation contract with the MOD.

BE11:08am

As in, the ten-year deal it signed in 2014

PM11:08am

ok...

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Which led the National Audit Office to grumble very shortly afterwards both about Capita's performance and its fees

BE11:08am

... which (pre costs) amounted to about half the £90m the MOD had paid between June 2014 and July 2016.

BE11:08am

The HOC PAC report on it's here, if anyone wants a reminder. https://publicatio...bacc/888/88802.htm

11:09 am
BE11:09am

And buried down there is £37m provision has been taken to cover the Connaught Unregulated Collective Investment Scheme collapse.

BE11:09am

Which -- absurdly! -- is still the subject of an FCA investigation.

PM11:09am

Oh that thing

11:09 am
PM11:09am

How many years has that been going for??

BE11:10am

Nearly a decade. You'll remember Capita was an administrator on what it initially called the Guaranteed Low Risk Income Fund, which it launched in 2008 then got shot of in late 2009.

BE11:10am

You may remember this thing offered returns in excess of 10% by writing short-term, very high interest bridging loans to property developers via a regulated lender called Tiuta Group.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

In 2008.

PM11:10am

Sheesh

PM11:10am

I do remember

11:10 am
BE11:10am

So .... Tiuta was suspended in 2012 .... which was some time after it was discovered to have a £20m gap in its accounts! Because it had been dipping into investor money to pay directors' salaries and operating costs!

BE11:11am

Anyway, seems like investors in the hilariously named Guaranteed Low Risk Income Fund will be getting some money soon, which is nice, assuming they're not all dead yet.

BE11:11am

There's a backgrounder on the scandal here: https://www.ft.com...-8b45-b8b81dd5d080

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Anyway, those are all just standard Capita being Capita items.

BE11:12am

What we get further up the statement is no update on a CEO appointment.

PM11:12am

ah

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Trading in transactional businesses is not recovering as hoped.

BE11:13am

New contract wins are weak, even allowing for a subdued market.

BE11:13am

Free cashflow's poor against forecasts.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

And no fewer than three major contracts are causing headaches.

Capita PLC (CPI:LSE): Last: 580.44, down 63.56 (-9.87%), High: 630.00, Low: 551.50, Volume: 3.76m
BE11:14am

Who can summarise here? How about Barclays.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

EBITA of £228m is 1% ahead of our estimates but slightly below the c£235m we estimated management were previously guiding to. PBT of £195m is c3% ahead of our estimates. EPS of 22.9p was ahead of our 22.7p. Dividend held flat (we assume a cut at the full year stage). 1H organic growth is -0.5% vs. our -3.5% - boosted by a £16m benefit from the reshaping of the DIO contract, not expected to reoccur in 2018. OUTLOOK: Full year guidance is for a ‘modest’ improvement in PBT in the 2H vs. 1H; our current FY17e forecast (£419m) implies an incremental £224m (+15% on 1H). Assuming modest suggests c5%, this implies FY PTP closer to £400m vs. consensus (company collected) expectations of c£420m (-5%). Management note a delay in targeted cost savings of c£10-15m and challenging conditions in some trading business. Overall cost saving targets remain unchanged. Leverage expected to be at the bottom end of 2.0-2.5x leverage range –although this could creep up to the middle of this range (vs. our 1.7x), if Capita unwinds its £120m receivables facility and due to IRFS 15 changes. Pipeline is weak £3.1bn (down on £3.8bn as at March 17). Aggregate contract wins/extensions is £403m, (vs. £879m 1H16) of which £109m is new contracts. Capita has also taken a £37m provision for potential financial penalties & legal fees from the FCA in regard the Capita’s operation of the Connaught fund over 2009-12. Whilst not expensive on c12.5x FY18e PE and c8x FY18e EV/EBITDA, slowing growth continues to pressure profitability and balance sheet leverage still looks full limiting room for manoeuvre. We are still waiting for a new CEO to be appointed.

BE11:15am

And Morgan Stanley.

BE11:15am

Numbers look disappointing and are difficult to read: Sales of £2,066m is -5% vs MSe, operating profit of £228m -5%, PBT £195m -3% vs £201m, EPS 22.9p - 3%. The focus is PBT given guidance of 1H17 not being below 2H16 (ex-disposals and accrued income w/o) of £195m, although no consensus, the company indicated that the numbers it had “were in the £190ms”. There is very little detail on WC (no note for CF statement or BS items). It also appears to have received a one-off £16m from being bought out of the DIO contract early; assuming this is the case would imply PBT of £179m, 11% below MSe. It expects less benefit from the £57m costs savings by 2018 in the current year. Forward looking metrics are also weak: contract wins are £403m vs £879m 1H16 (and will be nearly all renewals) and the pipeline is now £3.1bn (£3.8bn in March) and average contract length in the pipe 5.5yrs (7yrs March). The positive is ND, which at £1.6bn compares to MSe £1.64bn, and it expects to be at the bottom of 2-2.5x, but this is prior to IFRS 15 and unwinding receivables.

11:15 am
PM11:15am

Ok, I'm beaten back now

PM11:16am

Forget the market structure stuff

undefined
11:16 am
BE11:16am

Actually, though!

BE11:16am

I'm not sure if this is an example of market structure or something else .....

BE11:17am

But you might remember in the middle of last month there were highly credible rumours about a US thing called Calgon Carbon.

11:17 am
PM11:17am

Remind me

BE11:17am

We were on holiday when they first appeared, but we recapped here.

BE11:17am

https://ftalphavil...tslive/2017-08-14/

11:17 am
PM11:18am

Ah yes

PM11:18am

Calgon Carbon Corporation is a Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania based company that manufactures and markets products that remove contaminants and odors from liquids and gases, both for industrial, municipal, and consumer markets

BE11:18am

11:18 am
BE11:18am

There. Quote within a quote.

BE11:19am

So, as of this morning. https://www.reuter...-bln-idUST9N1LL01O

BE11:19am

Which is nice, as in right bidder and etc, but what to note here is the premium.

11:19 am
PM11:19am

That's a good hit Bryce!

BE11:20am

Not claiming it, because as I say, we were off air when the rumour was first doing the rounds.

BE11:20am

It's around a 68% premium though!

11:20 am
PM11:20am

woah

BE11:20am

For a rumour that was reported! Here and elsewhere!

BE11:21am

The price we were hearing was a dollar less than the Japanese have decided to pay, incidentally. Though usually with small US companies it's nearly impossible to get comfortable enough to report any of this stuff with certainty.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Because they can just keep schtum. It's a bit frustrating TBH.

BE11:22am

Anyway, that might be an example of market inefficiency. Maybe. or maybe not. Dunno.

undefined
11:22 am
PM11:23am

Quick Albert interlude

PM11:23am

If only cos we didn't both with Yellen

PM11:23am

Actually, Albert is going mainstream

11:23 am
PM11:23am

Or is it the other way round?

PM11:23am

Yeah, mainstream going Albert

PM11:24am

Let me just share the cover page

11:24 am
PM11:24am

Which seems to have been inspired by this big debt stuff that the Guardian are running at the mo

PM11:24am

Jill Treanor and colleagues

PM11:24am

It is remarkable how similar the US and UK macro situations often are. This was most evident in the run-up to the 2008 Global Financial Crisis (GFC) with both the Federal Reserve and Bank of England (BoE) asleep at the wheel, building a most precarious pyramid of prosperity upon the shifting sands of rampant credit growth and illusory housing wealth. These of all the major central banks were the most culpable in their incompetence and most prepared with disingenuous excuses. And 10 years on, not much has changed. The Fed and BoE are once again presiding over a credit bubble, with the BoE in particular suffering a painful episode of cognitive dissonance in an effort to shift the blame elsewhere. The credit bubble is everyone’s fault but theirs.

11:24 am
PM11:25am

In the wake of the 2008 GFC, the UK and US household sectors went through a heavy bout of de-leveraging. The dominant source of household credit in both countries is via mortgages, the growth of which has only recently recovered into the low single digits (around 3%). The problem instead now lies in unsecured credit, the growth of which has exploded above 10% in both countries.

PM11:25am

We have written on this topic before in the context of US and UK economic growth only being sustained by sharp declines in household saving ratios. But though I must revisit the issue after the UK’s Guardian newspaper (for non-UK clients it is similar to The New York Times) ran a huge feature on the desperate situation many of the JAMs (just about managing) now find themselves in – see article here. I do not think this debt time-bomb is specific to the UK. We are in a QE, zero interest rate world, where central banks are effectively force-feeding debt down borrowers’ throats. They did it in 2003-2007 and they are doing it again. Most of the liquidity merely swirls around financial markets, but there is certainly compelling evidence now of a consumer credit bubble in both the UK and US (as well as a corporate credit bubble in the US).

PM11:25am

But rather than the bubble itself it is the reaction of the BoE that I find most bizarre. Mark Carney warns darkly that “banks are forgetting the lessons of the past” and he recently increased bank capital requirements on consumer loans - link. But as Ed Conway of Sky News points out, at the same time it is warning of a consumer credit bubble, the BoE has just increased its programme of lending to banks at preferential rates to increase bank lending in things like, yes you’ve guessed it, consumer credit! As Ed says, this is like having your foot on the brake and the accelerator at the same time - link. This makes Governor Carney’s cautious statements about consumer credit look ridiculous and takes BoE monetary policy to a new level of schizophrenia.

11:25 am
PM11:26am

That's very un-PC use of schizophrenia.

PM11:26am

One last par

PM11:26am

The simple fact is monetary policy is way too loose in the UK as well as in the US, and let us not forget the BoE cut rates in the immediate aftermath of last July’s Brexit vote. Bubbles are appearing in areas like consumer credit because interest rates are far too low and need to be raised. And yes, when interest rates are excessively low, both borrowers and lenders do stupid things. But to ignore their own role in creating debt misery for millions, the BoE can only deal with its own cognitive dissonance by blaming someone else. When this debt bubble blows, I suspect citizens’ rage will be directed where it belongs

11:26 am
PM11:26am

I'd say consumer credit is out of control -- but not necessarily low rates themselves

PM11:27am

It's the explosion of outrageously high rates, pumped at consumers all day long

PM11:27am

But anyway

11:27 am
undefined
BE11:27am

Should probably mention Anglo.

PM11:27am

oh yeah -- from last night

11:27 am
Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 1,339, up 44.5 (+3.44%), High: 1,343, Low: 1,305, Volume: 3.31m
BE11:28am

Bloody shambles last night, is what it was.

BE11:28am

Because Volcan Investments, Anil Agarwal's family trust, appear to have sent out a draft press release to Bloomberg and no one else.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

So, Bloomberg flashed that Agarwal was acquiring 9%, citing a statement that wasn't on any wire and no-one else had seen.

PM11:00am

Welcome to Markets Live

BE11:30am

This is post UK close -- but Anglo doesn't just trade in the UK, of course. It ticks along on two dozen markets, many of which were open when Bloomberg flashed the story.

11:30 am
PM11:30am

Blimey

BE11:31am

Selective dissemination of price sensitive information, perhaps? I'm not a regulator, and try not to think like one, but if I were and/or did I'd probably be chewing my pencil a bit about that.

PM11:32am

Is the statement available anywhere now?

11:32 am
BE11:32am

I think so, it was emailed round by about 6pm last night.

BE11:32am

Haven't checked RNS etc though.

BE11:33am

So, this will need a little explanation of structure, which isn't simple.

11:32 am
PM11:33am

https://www.invest...1709201701333453R/

BE11:33am

HSBC .....

BE11:33am

We believe that the structure is similar to the one that was set up in Mar’17, which resulted in VI acquiring c13% of AAL’s ordinary shares. In additional to its direct 1.4% interest in AAL, VI will now have voting rights of c22% of AAL’s ordinary share capital; AAL’s second largest shareholder is SA’s Public Investment Corporation at 14%. The innovative structure set up in Mar’17 allowed VI to “borrow” its AAL shares for a three year period and was financed through a cUSD2.4bn mandatory exchangeable (convertible) bond with annual coupon payments of c4%pa. While VI has acquired the voting rights for these AAL shares, any dividends paid by AAL must flow through to the lender of the shares. The cost of the CBs are carried by VI and in Mar’20, VI will have the option of either retaining the AAL shares or redeeming the CBs in cas

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Y tho?

BE11:34am

Providing a platform for VED to merge with AAL is the obvious motive and using this structure has avoided VI paying a market premium to potentially acquire a significant block of AAL shares. While Agarwal has again stated that VI does not intend to make an offer to minorities, what this acquisition does do is give VI (and possibly VED) some strategic options in the advent that AAL becomes a corporate play at some future date. However, being Chairman of VED will make a motivation for a merger between AAL and VED even more difficult due to the inherent conflict of interest and potential corporate governance issues and more so given that AAL will (again) likely rebuff (and rightly so in our opinion) any attempt by VED or VI to merge the two companies. However, if AAL were to break up, depending upon what may transpire, maybe there would be some opportunity for some future deal-making, but again VI will also need to be mindful of the corporate governance difficulties that such a strategy may unfold. The bottom line is that if VED wants to acquire AAL, it would need to pay a full price; of course if this were to happen, VI would benefit.

PM11:35am

Wonder who came up with the structure here. No bank mentioned on the release -- or the one they pushed out in March

11:35 am
PM11:35am

https://www.invest...1703151723286082Z/

PM11:35am

Oh hang on, im blind

PM11:35am

JP Morgan

11:35 am
BE11:36am

.... who haven't published this morning.

BE11:36am

Have RBC instead.

BE11:36am

We see this investment as bringing Anil Agarwal to a position where he will be able to have a material say on any corporate a evolution (as well as having a very concentrated bet on commodity upside and/or Anglo rerating upside).

We recently spent a day with Anglo American and this reinforced our view on the compelling value story within the equity. Obviously, this investment should be seen to support this view, but we see this value story having been significantly enhanced by the recent deleveraging, which opens up optionality on the international balance sheet and hence strategic options. Management is focusing on potential high return investment at operations like Grosvenor and Orapa, a lowest quartile copper growth project in Quellavecho, and innovation, with some interesting potential implications for their copper cost positioning. This will occur while deleveraging continues to progress which should help to rerate the company, even in the absence of an eventual South African divestment/restructure. South Africa itself, especially Kumba with strong grade and lump premiums, is generating c. 7% of the c. 20% free cash yield and most of the dividend. Anglo equity also has a positive embedded option from the sense that a more business-friendly ANC leader emerging from the Leadership Conference in December could help to significantly close the valuation discount, in our view.

It remains to be seen if there are further ambitions from Volcan, but if anything we believe this should help to support to upside case and potentially accelerate a corporate restructuring. We continue to favour Anglo American amongst the London diversified miners.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

... "a material say on any corporate evolution" is a pleasant euphemism, though I imagine Mr Cutifani is using different words.

undefined
BE11:39am

(@RA: nothing on Glencore, no news on tape and shares down in line with the sector. Why do you ask?)

11:43 am

The stock reached 13 quid when the Tencent thing came out -- but despite the pull back it's had a hell of a run

undefined
11:45 am
BE11:45am

Back up into the regulated markets.

BE11:46am

..... And there's more pretty rubbish numbers from a pub operator.

Mitchells & Butlers PLC (MAB:LSE): Last: 235.70, down 11.5 (-4.65%), High: 248.40, Low: 232.80, Volume: 414.80k
11:46 am
PM11:46am

https://www.invest...1709210700043589R/

BE11:47am

Usual story really. Slowdown, weather, "market has been more challenging in recent weeks" .....

BE11:48am

LFLs down to +0.3%, which is a rather sharp drop not explained entirely by a bit of rain.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Here's Canaccord to summarise.

BE11:48am

L4L sales to mid-Sept (51 weeks) were +1.8% vs +1.9% at mid May (33 weeks including Easter). However, it has been a half of two quarters. L4L sales for the first 10 weeks of H2 were +2.6%, but L4L sales slumped to +0.3% in the last 8 weeks with the big delta being wet sales (+3.8% to -1.2% over the same periods). The big sunshine sensitive pubs, Vintage Inns, Premium Country Dining and selected urban pubs with outside drinking space, did not get sunshine they need to perform well. It's a highly operationally geared business. In contrast, L4L food sales remained ticked up slightly to +1.5% from +1.3% over the respective quarters. M&B's big carveries have provided some offset as they have continued to trade well over the summer.

BE11:49am

Resilience in "big carveries" ...... hm.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Although the L4L sales have been positive this year, the performance has not been enough to completely offset the cost headwinds and we forecast a 300bps decline in EBIT margin to 14.9% and then remaining stable in subsequent years. M&B recorded a peak EBIT margin of 20.3% in 2000 and has been in constant gentle decline since then.
In FY17 M&B has opened 13 new sites, completed 236 conversions and disposed of 79 pubs, of which 73 were sold as a package which completed in July. Disposal proceeds were £46m. It needs to keep reshaping the estate to reflect moving trading patterns.

BE11:50am

M&B is trading on PE multiples of 7.0x for FY17E (53 weeks) rising to 7.3x for FY18E, EV/EBITDA multiples of 7.2x and 7.3x, and a FCF yield of 15.1% and 14.4%. The FY17E NAV/share of 365p should act as an underpin for our 240p target price, which is based on a PE of c.6.5x, EV/EBITDA of 7.0x and FCF yield of c.16.0% for FY17E.

BE11:51am

Sellside mostly saying "reassuring under the circumstances, forecasts unchanged" .....

11:51 am
BE11:52am

Not entirely clear why the shares are down 5% because it rained a bit. But it's not my job to argue with Mr Market.

BE11:52am

Citi.

BE11:52am

51 week LFLs are +1.8% (Citi FY17E +1.3%), with +0.3% for the last 8 weeks to 16 September (Citi -2.0%), a sharp slowdown from the previous 10 weeks at +2.6%. This latest trading is broadly in line with Coffer Peach July-August data which averaged +0.4%, although early Sept was likely weaker given tough weather comps. The slowdown is driven by falling drink sales, with recent LFLs down -1.2% (previous 10 weeks +3.8%) while food remained stable at +1.5% (previous 10 weeks +1.3%). While weather likely had an impact, typically affecting wet-led pubs more than food-led, we think the consumer environment appears generally softer. After adjusting for price and mix changes, we think that food and drink volumes are likely declining 3-4% in the most recent period. Management reiterates that FY17 margins will be below last year due to inflationary cost pressures (Citi FY17E EBITA -90bps to 14.3%)

11:53 am
BE11:53am

We expect no change to consensus given that the overall performance for the year is broadly in line with expectations but the recent slower trading has caused us to recently lower our sector-wide LFL assumptions for FY18 by 2pp and we continue to have a cautious view on the sector. Recent trading compares to Greene King 1Q18 LFLs of -1.2% and JDW +6.1% for the first "few weeks" of its FY18. We forecast FY17E EBITA -3% yoy to £175m (Cons £180m).

BE11:53am

Meh.

undefined
11:53 am
PM11:54am

Just having a look round...

BE11:54am

There's not much, for a Thursday.

BE11:55am

Guess it's a bad day to putout a big call, because you'll be a hostage to the Fed overhang.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

There's JMAT, as noted on the right, which we'll get to in a moment ....

BE11:56am

..... based on its mid-term targets and junk.

BE11:56am

But there's also Kepler on Ryanair, raking back over the ECJ thing and fearing the worst.

11:56 am
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYA:LSE): Last: 16.42, down 0.09 (-0.55%), High: 16.50, Low: 15.85, Volume: 2.35m
BE11:57am

Despite Ryanair’s CEO saying that this “will not affect our self-employed model”, we see a risk that a pilot classified as a freelancer under Irish law, might be considered as regular employee in another country (e.g. Germany), which is likely to
result in higher social contributions for Ryanair that may have to be paid retroactively. We see a risk that the ECJ verdict will result in an increased number of claims against Ryanair all over Europe. Ryanair’s CEO mentioned on Monday that the ruling could give unions more opportunities to take the airline to court.

BE11:58am

Plus, you have O'Leary all over the wires this morning talking about how any pilot who works to rule will be dead to him.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

On that theme ......

BE11:58am

On Friday evening, the company announced they will cancel 40-50 flights a day over six weeks, without giving details on which flights, creating “a significant degree of uncertainty among our entire customer base that their flights might be cancelled by September and October”. The cancellations “will not affect our guidance for the full year, but it will have a reputation impact for which I sincerely apologize”, Ryanair’s CEO said. We believe that despite efforts by the company to improve its reputation over the last several quarters, it continues to struggle against the perception of its customers, which may be one reason for the price pressure it has been facing (after a price decline of 15-17% during the last winter flight schedule, the company guides for price declines of c. 8% during the next winter flight schedule).

BE11:58am

So .............

11:58 am
BE11:59am

We increase our expectations for ancillary revenues in 2018E (in line with guidance) which is largely offset by EUR25m in additional costs incurred by the current flight cancellation. Our FY net income of EUR1,391m is marginally below the company’s guidance of EUR1.4-1.45bn. We value the stock based on its historical five-year P/E multiple of 14.5x, to which we apply a discount of 10% to account for uncertainties related to Brexit. Our TP remains unchanged at EUR14.5, which implies a 12% downside potential to the current share price. We downgrade the stock from Hold to Reduce.

undefined
BE11:59am

And -- yes, okay! ROTR, we hear you! -- JMAT.

11:59 am
PM11:59am

Goodness, J Matt up 9% now

Johnson Matthey PLC (JMAT:LSE): Last: 3,179, up 221 (+7.47%), High: 3,215, Low: 2,972, Volume: 1.43m
PM12:00pm

3227 live

11:59 am
BE12:00pm

Investor day, ahead of which it's updated the mid-term targets.

PM12:00pm

https://www.invest...1709210700053636R/

BE12:01pm

As in, transition into a growth company rather than one that relies too much on catalytic converters fitted to diesel vans.

12:01 pm
PM12:01pm

battery stuff causing excitement?

PM12:01pm

Im always confused by stuff on new battery tech

PM12:02pm

One minute reading that the revolution is coming, next reminded that batteries doin't follow moore's law

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

We're getting a £200m investment in battery materials, where JMAT is considered to be somewhat behind the bleeding edge of technology.

BE12:03pm

And, no, batteries are chemistry. And while Gordon Moore was a chemist, he didn't really fulfil his potential there.

BE12:03pm

The slacker.

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Let me get Citi to summarise what's been said.

BE12:04pm

The group confirmed its guidance for FY17/18 with sales growth
at c.6% (in c.c). Fx outlook is unchanged – it is expected to benefit operating profit by £13m with estimated restructuring benefits in this financial year unchanged at £10m. Over the mid-term the group is expecting to achieve a ROIC of 20%, deliver a mid to high single digit EPS CAGR and continue a progressive dividend policy. The press release also notes that the presentation will outline a further £50m of savings (from procurement – over a period of 3 years starting from FY 2018/19). They will reinvest these savings with the balance for margin expansion. These savings come in addition to the £25m of cost savings announced in June 2017

BE12:04pm

Divisional Strategy – Johnson Matthey expects their Clean Air division (emissions catalyst) to deliver high single digit sales growth in the next 2-3 years from share gains already achieved in Europe LDV and from upcoming tighter legislation. Longer term growth is also expected and will be sustained by regulatory tightening in Asia, and JM’s strong position in HDD, partially offset by the move away from diesel engines in Europe and the increasing penetration of battery electric in light duty. In Efficient Natural Resources, it expects to deliver above market sales growth and improve operating margins with a focus on efficiency. For the Health division, the group expects double digit sales growth and margin expansion from its deeper pipeline of new products beginning in ‘19/20. In New Markets, the group is focusing on battery materials technology and announced a £200m investment (in 2018) to build capacity and to drive growth. They noted that once BEV penetration increases to c.10% they expect this market to be worth more than $30bn in sales.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

In our view, the CMD will highlight how JMAT has the technical,
technological and materials skill to deliver growth in its changing markets. Overall, the outlook presented by the group is consistent with our view set out in JMAT.L - From Platinum to Nickel with a bit of Phosphate in Between. We see the investment in battery materials as key, and expect JMAT to be able to make meaningful strides in this business given their technological expertise and OEM relationships. On a risk adjusted basis we see £38 as fairly valuing JMAT’s potential. As the conflicting dynamics and JMAT’s ability to compete successfully become clearer, improving sentiment is likely to support rerating and outperformance.

BE12:05pm

And Deutsche Bank.

BE12:05pm

Overall, the release has something for the bulls and something for bears. Targeted growth does not imply material upgrades and growth is expected to moderate in Catalysts. However Catalysts is still expected to grow for at least the next ten years and their EV proposition is gaining pace along with Health giving confidence in the longer term growth of the company. At 13x 17/18 P/E, the stock is one of the cheapest specialty names in the sector with these long- term structural growth undervalued. BUY
